title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff, family child care providers, and adults living in the home of a family child care provider in states receiving funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act. The check includes searches of national and state criminal databases, as well as abuse and neglect registries. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires criminal background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state registries for abuse and neglect, as well as FBI fingerprint checks. Child care providers are ineligible for funds if a felony conviction for crimes like child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, or homicide is found during the background check. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state registries for abuse and neglect, as well as FBI fingerprint checks. Providers are disqualified from receiving funds if they have felony convictions for crimes like child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, rape, sexual assault, homicide, or drug offenses within 5 years prior to the background check submission. Providers must request a State and national criminal background check through the designated State agency. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" requires background checks for child care staff members, family providers, and adults residing in a provider's home every 5 years. Prospective staff members and providers must undergo checks before starting their roles. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates background checks every 5 years for child care staff, family providers, and adults living in a provider's home. Only one check is needed per 5-year period, and results must be provided within 10 business days of the request. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" requires background checks every 5 years for child care staff, family providers, and adults in a provider's home. States must provide a copy of the background check upon request and ensure accuracy by obtaining dispositions of arrests, correcting inaccurate information, completing incomplete entries, and taking steps to improve accuracy. Appeals are also allowed. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates background checks every 5 years for child care staff and family providers. States must ensure accuracy by obtaining arrest dispositions, correcting inaccuracies, and allowing appeals within 30 days of receiving results. The State agency must make a final ruling on eligibility and provide specific findings to the individual. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 requires background checks every 5 years for child care staff and family providers. States must ensure accuracy, correct any inaccuracies, and allow appeals within 30 days of receiving results. A State may collect a fee not exceeding $36 per criminal background check to cover administration costs. States must implement these requirements within 3 years of the Act's enactment, with the possibility of extensions granted by the Secretary. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows the Secretary to grant a 2-year extension to States making a good faith effort to meet requirements. Definitions include 'adult' as 18 years or older, 'child care provider' as licensed or regulated centers, and 'child care staff member' as individuals providing child care services. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 defines 'child care staff member' as an individual providing child care services for compensation, and 'family child care provider' as someone who provides care for fewer than 24 hours per day in a private residence. Authorization of appropriations is granted for conducting criminal background checks. Authorization of appropriations is granted to conduct criminal background checks for child care staff members and family child care providers.
